org.joda.pa

Interface MetaProperty<P>

  • Type Parameters:
    P - the type of the property content

    public interface MetaProperty<P>
    A meta-property defines aspects of a property, such as the type and name.

    A property provides access to a single piece of information on a bean.

    A MetaProperty is obtained from a MetaBean.

    • Method Detail

      • metaBean

        MetaBean metaBean()
        Gets the meta-bean that defines this meta-property.

        Each meta-property is fully owned by a single meta-bean.

        Returns:
        the meta-bean, not null

      • name

        String name()
        Gets the property name.

        The property name is intended to follow lowerCamelCase naming. A traditional Java Bean style getFoo() and setFoo() will lead to a property name of foo.

        It is recommended to use property names matching the regular expression '[a-z][A-Za-z0-9_]*'. Doing so allows the property name to be used in other contexts, such as JSON or XML data formats.

        Returns:
        the name of the property, not empty

      • declaringType

        default Class<?> declaringType()
        Gets the type that declares the property, represented as a Class.

        This is the type of the bean where the property is declared.

        The default implementation returns the result of metaBean().beanType().

        Returns:
        the type declaring the property, not null

      • propertyType

        Class<P> propertyType()
        Gets the type of the property represented as a Class.

        This is the type of the property. For example, the surname of a person would typically be a String.

        Returns:
        the type of the property, not null

      • propertyGenericType

        default Type propertyGenericType()
        Gets the generic types of the property.

        This provides access to the generic type of the property. This is primarily useful for determining the generic parameters of collections.

        The default implementation returns the result of propertyType().

        Returns:
        the full generic type of the property, not null

      • annotations

        java.util.stream.Stream<Annotation> annotations()
        Gets the stream of annotations associated with this property.

        The annotations are queried from the property. This is typically accomplished by querying the annotations of an underlying Field or Method however any strategy is permitted.

        If the implementation has a mutable set of annotations, then the result of this method must stream over those annotations in existence when this method is called to avoid concurrency issues.

        Returns:
        the stream of annotations on the property, not null

      • annotations

        default <A extends Annotation> java.util.stream.Stream<A> annotations(Class<A> annotationType)
        Gets the stream of annotations associated with this property by type.

        The annotations are queried from the property, filtering by type. This is typically accomplished by querying the annotations of an underlying Field or Method however any strategy is permitted.

        Call Stream.findFirst() on the result to obtain the first matching annotation if the type is not Repeatable.

        If the implementation has a mutable set of annotations, then the result of this method must stream over those annotations in existence when this method is called to avoid concurrency issues.

        The default implementation applies a filter and cast to the result of annotations().

        Type Parameters:
        A - the annotation type
        Parameters:
        annotationType - the annotation type to find, not null
        Returns:
        the annotations matching the specified type, not null

      • isDerived

        default boolean isDerived()
        Checks whether this property is derived or not.

        A derived property derives its value from one or more other properties. As such, the value of a derived property is not part of the essential state of the bean. Some tools, such as a serialization framework, may choose to omit derived properties as they can be recreated by the client.

        The default implementation returns false.

        Returns:
        true if this property is derived

      • isBuildable

        boolean isBuildable()
        Checks whether this property is buildable or not.

        A buildable property can be passed into the BeanBuilder of the meta-bean. If this method returns true then BeanBuilder.set() must succeed given valid arguments. If this method returns false then BeanBuilder.set() must throw UnsupportedOperationException.

        Returns:
        true if this property is buildable

      • isMutable

        boolean isMutable()
        Checks whether this property is mutable or not.

        A mutable property allows the set(Object, Object) method to be invoked. If this method returns true then set() must succeed given valid arguments. If this method returns false then set() must throw UnsupportedOperationException.

        Returns:
        true if this property is mutable

      • get

        P get(Object bean)
        Gets the value of the property for the specified bean.

        For a standard Java Bean, this is equivalent to calling getFoo() on the bean. Alternate implementations may perform any logic to obtain the value.

        Parameters:
        bean - the bean to query, not null
        Returns:
        the value of the property on the specified bean, may be null
        Throws:
        ClassCastException - if the bean is of an incorrect type
        UnsupportedOperationException - if the property is write-only

      • set

        void set(Object bean,
         Object value)
        Sets the value of the property on the specified bean.

        The value must be of the correct type for the property. For a standard Java Bean, this is equivalent to calling setFoo() on the bean. Alternate implementations may perform any logic to change the value.

        The argument value is not generic (in P) because this would prevent calling set on MetaProperty<?>. Since meta-properties will often be handled by frameworks, this is a common use-case which needs to be supported.

        Parameters:
        bean - the bean to update, not null
        value - the value to set into the property on the specified bean, may be null
        Throws:
        ClassCastException - if the bean is of an incorrect type or if the value is of an invalid type for the property
        UnsupportedOperationException - if the property is read-only
        RuntimeException - if the value is rejected by the property

      • equals

        boolean equals(Object obj)
        Checks if this meta-property equals another.

        Two properties are equal if they provide access to the same value. This is typically accomplished by comparing the property name and declaring class. The value of the property must not be used.

        Overrides:
        equals in class Object
        Parameters:
        obj - the other meta-property, null returns false
        Returns:
        true if equal

      • hashCode

        int hashCode()
        Returns a suitable hash code.

        Returns a hash code compatible with the definition of equals(Object).

        Overrides:
        hashCode in class Object
        Returns:
        the hash code
